üá∫üá∏ To people of Russia

There is a war in Ukraine right now. The forces of the Russian Federation are attacking civilian infrastructure in [Kharkiv][1], [Kyiv][2], [Chernihiv][3], [Sumy][4], [Irpin][5] and dozens of other cities. People are dying ‚Äì both civilians and military servicemen, including Russian conscripts who were thrown into the fighting. In order to deprive its own people of access to information, the government of the Russian Federation has forbidden calling a war a war, shut down independent media and is passing a number of dictatorial laws. These laws are meant to silence all those who are against war. You can be jailed for multiple years for simply calling for peace. Do not be silent! Silence is a sign that you accept the Russian government's policy. You can choose NOT TO BE SILENT.

  • [1] https://cloudfront-us-east-2.images.arcpublishing.com/reuters/P7K2MSZDGFMIJPDD7CI2GIROJI.jpg "Kharkiv under attack"
  • [2] https://gdb.voanews.com/01bd0000-0aff-0242-fad0-08d9fc92c5b3_cx0_cy5_cw0_w1023_r1_s.jpg "Kyiv under attack"
  • [3] https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/163DD/production/_123510119_hi074310744.jpg "Chernihiv under attack"
  • [4] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8K-bkqKKf2A "Sumy under attack"
  • [5] https://cloudfront-us-east-2.images.arcpublishing.com/reuters/K4MTMLEHTRKGFK3GSKAT4GR3NE.jpg "Irpin under attack"

"\x00\x00\xfe\xff" => 4, // UTF-32 (BE) BOM ' √æ√ø' => 6, // UTF-32 (BE) BOM as "WINDOWS-1252" "\xff\xfe\x00\x00" => 4, // UTF-32 (LE) BOM '√ø√æ ' => 6, // UTF-32 (LE) BOM as "WINDOWS-1252" "\xfe\xff" => 2, // UTF-16 (BE) BOM '√æ√ø' => 4, // UTF-16 (BE) BOM as "WINDOWS-1252" "\xff\xfe" => 2, // UTF-16 (LE) BOM '√ø√æ' => 4, ]

filter_input_array()

UTF8.php : 2065

"filter_input_array()"-wrapper with normalizes to UTF-8 NFC, converting from WINDOWS-1252 when needed.

public static filter_input_array(int $type[, array<string, mixed>|null $definition = null ][, bool $add_empty = true ]) : array<string, mixed>|false|null

Gets external variables and optionally filters them.

EXAMPLE: // _GET['foo'] = 'bar'; UTF8::filter_input_array(INPUT_GET, array('foo' => 'FILTER_UNSAFE_RAW')); // array('bar')

Parameters
$type : int

One of INPUT_GET, INPUT_POST, INPUT_COOKIE, INPUT_SERVER, or INPUT_ENV.

$definition : array<string, mixed>|null = null

[optional]

An array defining the arguments. A valid key is a string containing a variable name and a valid value is either a filter type, or an array optionally specifying the filter, flags and options. If the value is an array, valid keys are filter which specifies the filter type, flags which specifies any flags that apply to the filter, and options which specifies any options that apply to the filter. See the example below for a better understanding.

This parameter can be also an integer holding a filter constant. Then all values in the input array are filtered by this filter.

$add_empty : bool = true

[optional]

Add missing keys as NULL to the return value.

Tags
see
http://php.net/manual/en/function.filter-input-array.php
psalm-pure
Return values
array<string, mixed>|false|null —

An array containing the values of the requested variables on success, or FALSE on failure. An array value will be FALSE if the filter fails, or NULL if the variable is not set. Or if the flag FILTER_NULL_ON_FAILURE is used, it returns FALSE if the variable is not set and NULL if the filter fails.

filter_var()

UTF8.php : 2146

"filter_var()"-wrapper with normalizes to UTF-8 NFC, converting from WINDOWS-1252 when needed.

public static filter_var(float|int|string|null $variable[, int $filter = FILTER_DEFAULT ][, int|array<string|int, int>|null $options = null ]) : mixed

Filters a variable with a specified filter.

EXAMPLE: UTF8::filter_var('-ABC-‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ-', FILTER_VALIDATE_URL); // false

Parameters
$variable : float|int|string|null

Value to filter.

$filter : int = FILTER_DEFAULT

[optional]

The ID of the filter to apply. The manual page lists the available filters.

$options : int|array<string|int, int>|null = null

[optional]

Associative array of options or bitwise disjunction of flags. If filter accepts options, flags can be provided in "flags" field of array. For the "callback" filter, callable type should be passed. The callback must accept one argument, the value to be filtered, and return the value after filtering/sanitizing it.

// for filters that accept options, use this format $options = array( 'options' => array( 'default' => 3, // value to return if the filter fails // other options here 'min_range' => 0 ), 'flags' => FILTER_FLAG_ALLOW_OCTAL, ); $var = filter_var('0755', FILTER_VALIDATE_INT, $options); // for filter that only accept flags, you can pass them directly $var = filter_var('oops', FILTER_VALIDATE_BOOLEAN, FILTER_NULL_ON_FAILURE); // for filter that only accept flags, you can also pass as an array $var = filter_var('oops', FILTER_VALIDATE_BOOLEAN, array('flags' => FILTER_NULL_ON_FAILURE)); // callback validate filter function foo($value) { // Expected format: Surname, GivenNames if (strpos($value, ", ") === false) return false; list($surname, $givennames) = explode(", ", $value, 2); $empty = (empty($surname) || empty($givennames)); $notstrings = (!is_string($surname) || !is_string($givennames)); if ($empty || $notstrings) { return false; } else { return $value; } } $var = filter_var('Doe, Jane Sue', FILTER_CALLBACK, array('options' => 'foo'));

Tags
see
http://php.net/manual/en/function.filter-var.php
psalm-pure
Return values
mixed —

The filtered data, or FALSE if the filter fails.

html_entity_decode()

UTF8.php : 2959

UTF-8 version of html_entity_decode()

public static html_entity_decode(string $str[, int|null $flags = null ][, string $encoding = 'UTF-8' ]) : string

The reason we are not using html_entity_decode() by itself is because while it is not technically correct to leave out the semicolon at the end of an entity most browsers will still interpret the entity correctly. html_entity_decode() does not convert entities without semicolons, so we are left with our own little solution here. Bummer.

Convert all HTML entities to their applicable characters.

INFO: opposite to UTF8::html_encode()

EXAMPLE: UTF8::html_entity_decode('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ'); // '‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ'

Parameters
$str : string

The input string.

$flags : int|null = null

[optional]

A bitmask of one or more of the following flags, which specify how to handle quotes and which document type to use. The default is ENT_COMPAT | ENT_HTML401.

Available flags constants
Constant Name Description
ENT_COMPAT Will convert double-quotes and leave single-quotes alone.
ENT_QUOTES Will convert both double and single quotes.
ENT_NOQUOTES Will leave both double and single quotes unconverted.
ENT_HTML401 Handle code as HTML 4.01.
ENT_XML1 Handle code as XML 1.
ENT_XHTML Handle code as XHTML.
ENT_HTML5 Handle code as HTML 5.

$encoding : string = 'UTF-8'

[optional]

Set the charset for e.g. "mb_" function

htmlentities()

UTF8.php : 3167

Convert all applicable characters to HTML entities: UTF-8 version of htmlentities().

public static htmlentities(string $str[, int $flags = ENT_COMPAT ][, string $encoding = 'UTF-8' ][, bool $double_encode = true ]) : string

EXAMPLE: UTF8::htmlentities('<ÁôΩ-√∂√§√º>'); // '<ÁôΩ-√∂√§√º>'

Parameters
$str : string

The input string.

$flags : int = ENT_COMPAT

[optional]

A bitmask of one or more of the following flags, which specify how to handle quotes, invalid code unit sequences and the used document type. The default is ENT_COMPAT | ENT_HTML401.

Available flags constants
Constant Name Description
ENT_COMPAT Will convert double-quotes and leave single-quotes alone.
ENT_QUOTES Will convert both double and single quotes.
ENT_NOQUOTES Will leave both double and single quotes unconverted.
ENT_IGNORE Silently discard invalid code unit sequences instead of returning an empty string. Using this flag is discouraged as it may have security implications.
ENT_SUBSTITUTE Replace invalid code unit sequences with a Unicode Replacement Character U+FFFD (UTF-8) or &#38;#FFFD; (otherwise) instead of returning an empty string.
ENT_DISALLOWED Replace invalid code points for the given document type with a Unicode Replacement Character U+FFFD (UTF-8) or &#38;#FFFD; (otherwise) instead of leaving them as is. This may be useful, for instance, to ensure the well-formedness of XML documents with embedded external content.
ENT_HTML401 Handle code as HTML 4.01.
ENT_XML1 Handle code as XML 1.
ENT_XHTML Handle code as XHTML.
ENT_HTML5 Handle code as HTML 5.

$encoding : string = 'UTF-8'

[optional]

Like htmlspecialchars, htmlentities takes an optional third argument encoding which defines encoding used in conversion. Although this argument is technically optional, you are highly encouraged to specify the correct value for your code.

$double_encode : bool = true

[optional]

When double_encode is turned off PHP will not encode existing html entities. The default is to convert everything.

Tags
see
http://php.net/manual/en/function.htmlentities.php
psalm-pure
Return values
string —

The encoded string.

If the input string contains an invalid code unit sequence within the given encoding an empty string will be returned, unless either the ENT_IGNORE or ENT_SUBSTITUTE flags are set.

Available flags constants
Constant Name Description

ENT_QUOTES Will convert both double and single quotes.

Defines encoding used in conversion.

For the purposes of this function, the encodings ISO-8859-1, ISO-8859-15, UTF-8, cp866, cp1251, cp1252, and KOI8-R are effectively equivalent, provided the string itself is valid for the encoding, as the characters affected by htmlspecialchars occupy the same positions in all of these encodings.

json_decode()

UTF8.php : 4128

(PHP 5 &gt;= 5.2.0, PECL json &gt;= 1.2.0)<br/> Decodes a JSON string

public static json_decode(string $json[, bool $assoc = false ][, int $depth = 512 ][, int $options = 0 ]) : mixed

EXAMPLE: UTF8::json_decode('[1,"\u00a5","\u00e4"]'); // array(1, '¬•', '√§')

Parameters
$json : string

The json string being decoded.

This function only works with UTF-8 encoded strings.

PHP implements a superset of JSON - it will also encode and decode scalar types and NULL. The JSON standard only supports these values when they are nested inside an array or an object.

$assoc : bool = false

[optional]

When TRUE, returned objects will be converted into associative arrays.

$depth : int = 512

[optional]

User specified recursion depth.

$options : int = 0

[optional]

Bitmask of JSON decode options. Currently only JSON_BIGINT_AS_STRING is supported (default is to cast large integers as floats)

Tags
see
http://php.net/manual/en/function.json-decode.php
psalm-pure
Return values
mixed —

The value encoded in json in appropriate PHP type. Values true, false and null (case-insensitive) are returned as TRUE, FALSE and NULL respectively. NULL is returned if the json cannot be decoded or if the encoded data is deeper than the recursion limit.

EXAMPLE: UTF8::parse_str('I√±t√´rn√¢ti√¥n√©√†liz√¶ti√∏n=Ê∏¨Ë©¶&arr[]=foo+Ê∏¨Ë©¶&arr[]=‡∫Å‡∫≤‡∫ô‡∫ó‡∫ª‡∫î‡∫™‡∫≠‡∫ö', $array); echo $array['I√±t√´rn√¢ti√¥n√©√†liz√¶ti√∏n']; // 'Ê∏¨Ë©¶'

Parameters
$str : string

The input string.

$result : array<string, mixed>

The result will be returned into this reference parameter.

$clean_utf8 : bool = false

[optional]

Remove non UTF-8 chars from the string.

Tags
see
http://php.net/manual/en/function.parse-str.php

str_replace()

UTF8.php : 7369

INFO: This is only a wrapper for "str_replace()" -> the original functions is already UTF-8 safe.

public static str_replace(string|array<string|int, string> $search, string|array<string|int, string> $replace, string|array<string|int, string> $subject[, int|null &$count = null ]) : string|array<string|int, string>

Replace all occurrences of the search string with the replacement string

Parameters
$search : string|array<string|int, string>

The value being searched for, otherwise known as the needle. An array may be used to designate multiple needles.

$replace : string|array<string|int, string>

The replacement value that replaces found search values. An array may be used to designate multiple replacements.

$subject : string|array<string|int, string>

The string or array of strings being searched and replaced on, otherwise known as the haystack.

If subject is an array, then the search and replace is performed with every entry of subject, and the return value is an array as well.

$count : int|null = null

[optional]

If passed, this will hold the number of matched and replaced needles.

Tags
see
http://php.net/manual/en/function.str-replace.php
psalm-pure

phpstan-return

deprecated

please use \str_replace() instead

Return values

This function returns a string or an array with the replaced values.

str_word_count()

UTF8.php : 9069

Get the number of words in a specific string.

public static str_word_count(string $str[, int $format = 0 ][, string $char_list = '' ]) : int|array<string|int, string>

EXAMPLES: // format: 0 -> return only word count (int) // UTF8::str_word_count('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ √∂√§√º abc#c'); // 4 UTF8::str_word_count('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ √∂√§√º abc#c', 0, '#'); // 3

// format: 1 -> return words (array) // UTF8::str_word_count('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ √∂√§√º abc#c', 1); // array('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ', '√∂√§√º', 'abc', 'c') UTF8::str_word_count('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ √∂√§√º abc#c', 1, '#'); // array('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ', '√∂√§√º', 'abc#c')

// format: 2 -> return words with offset (array) // UTF8::str_word_count('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ √∂√§√º ab#c', 2); // array(0 => '‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ', 5 => '√∂√§√º', 9 => 'abc', 13 => 'c') UTF8::str_word_count('‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ √∂√§√º ab#c', 2, '#'); // array(0 => '‰∏≠ÊñáÁ©∫ÁôΩ', 5 => '√∂√§√º', 9 => 'abc#c')

Parameters
$str : string

The input string.

$format : int = 0

[optional]

0 => return a number of words (default)
1 => return an array of words
2 => return an array of words with word-offset as key

$char_list : string = ''

[optional]

Additional chars that contains to words and do not start a new word.

Tags
psalm-pure
Return values
int|array<string|int, string> —

The number of words in the string.

substr_replace()

UTF8.php : 11941

Replace text within a portion of a string.

public static substr_replace(string|array<string|int, string> $str, string|array<string|int, string> $replacement, int|array<string|int, int> $offset[, int|array<string|int, int>|null $length = null ][, string $encoding = 'UTF-8' ]) : string|array<string|int, string>

EXAMPLE: UTF8::substr_replace(array('I√±t√´rn√¢ti√¥n√†liz√¶ti√∏n', 'foo'), '√¶', 1); // array('I√¶√±t√´rn√¢ti√¥n√†liz√¶ti√∏n', 'f√¶oo')

source: https://gist.github.com/stemar/8287074

Parameters
$str : string|array<string|int, string>

The input string or an array of stings.

$replacement : string|array<string|int, string>

The replacement string or an array of stings.

$offset : int|array<string|int, int>

If start is positive, the replacing will begin at the start'th offset into string.

If start is negative, the replacing will begin at the start'th character from the end of string.

$length : int|array<string|int, int>|null = null

[optional]

If given and is positive, it represents the length of the portion of string which is to be replaced. If it is negative, it represents the number of characters from the end of string at which to stop replacing. If it is not given, then it will default to strlen( string ); i.e. end the replacing at the end of string. Of course, if length is zero then this function will have the effect of inserting replacement into string at the given start offset.

$encoding : string = 'UTF-8'

[optional]

Set the charset for e.g. "mb_" function

Tags
psalm-pure

The result string is returned. If string is an array then array is returned.

to_utf8()

UTF8.php : 12400

This function leaves UTF-8 characters alone, while converting almost all non-UTF8 to UTF8.

public static to_utf8(string|array<string|int, string> $str[, bool $decode_html_entity_to_utf8 = false ]) : string|array<string|int, string>
  • It decode UTF-8 codepoints and Unicode escape sequences.
  • It assumes that the encoding of the original string is either WINDOWS-1252 or ISO-8859.
  • WARNING: It does not remove invalid UTF-8 characters, so you maybe need to use "UTF8::clean()" for this case.

EXAMPLE: UTF8::to_utf8(["\u0063\u0061\u0074"]); // array('cat')

Parameters
$str : string|array<string|int, string>

Any string or array of strings.

$decode_html_entity_to_utf8 : bool = false

Set to true, if you need to decode html-entities.

Tags
psalm-pure
template

TToUtf8

phpstan-param

to_utf8_string()

UTF8.php : 12437

This function leaves UTF-8 characters alone, while converting almost all non-UTF8 to UTF8.

public static to_utf8_string(string $str[, bool $decode_html_entity_to_utf8 = false ]) : string
  • It decode UTF-8 codepoints and Unicode escape sequences.
  • It assumes that the encoding of the original string is either WINDOWS-1252 or ISO-8859.
  • WARNING: It does not remove invalid UTF-8 characters, so you maybe need to use "UTF8::clean()" for this case.

EXAMPLE: UTF8::to_utf8_string("\u0063\u0061\u0074"); // 'cat'

Parameters
$str : string

Any string.

$decode_html_entity_to_utf8 : bool = false

Set to true, if you need to decode html-entities.

Tags
psalm-pure
Return values
string —

The UTF-8 encoded string

trim()

UTF8.php : 12626

Strip whitespace or other characters from the beginning and end of a UTF-8 string.

public static trim([string $str = '' ][, string|null $chars = null ]) : string

INFO: This is slower then "trim()"

We can only use the original-function, if we use <= 7-Bit in the string / chars but the check for ASCII (7-Bit) cost more time, then we can safe here.

[optional]

If this flag is true, then the method will add a $break at the end of the result string.
